questionIntro: A 35-year-old man sustains an anterior dislocation of the shoulder.  Cutaneous sensation over the lower half of the deltoid muscle is impaired.
question: Which one of the following nerves has been damaged?

choiceResponses.option1: The axillary nerve supplies the deltoid muscle.
choiceResponses.option2: Injury of this nerve at a level above the elbow results in loss of pronation and a reduction in flexion of the hand at the wrist.
choiceResponses.option3: Isolated injury causes weakness of elbow flexion and supination of the forearm.
choiceResponses.option4: Supplies the extensor compartment of the lower arm.
choiceResponses.option5: Sever entrapment or complete severing of the ulnar nerve can present clinically as an ulnar claw.

questionIntro: A junior doctor wants to carry out a lumbar puncture on a patient with meningism.  He is unsure about at what level of the spine the procedure should be carried out and does not want to damage the spinal cord.
question: At what level does the spinal cord end?

choiceResponses.option1: This is the level at which the abdominal aorta enters the abdomen through the diaphragm.
choiceResponses.option2: The spinal cord ends at the level of L1.
choiceResponses.option3: This is the level of the bifurcation of the aorta.
choiceResponses.option4: This is the level at which the iliac veins become the inferior vena cava.
choiceResponses.option5: This is the level at which the oesophagus enters the abdomen.

questionIntro: A 71-year-old woman has a total hip replacement and postoperatively develops a Trendelenburg gait.
question: Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?

choices.option5: Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh

choiceResponses.option1: The femoral nerve supplies the anterior thigh muscles.
choiceResponses.option2: The sciatic nerve supplies the hamstrings and other hip extensors.
choiceResponses.option3: The obturator nerve supplies the hip adductors.
choiceResponses.option4: A superior gluteal nerve injury would paralyze the gluteus medius causing a Trendelenburg gait.
choiceResponses.option5: This innervates the skin on the lateral part of the thigh.
